DOCNAME: CASE OF AVRAM AND OTHERS v. MOLDOVA
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection joined to merits and dismissed (victim);Violation of Art. 8;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Corneliu Bîrsan;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Luis López Guerra;Mihai Poalelungi;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE respectively and live in GPE . CARDINAL of the applicants are journalists , one is a teacher of NORP and another is a librarian . They are friends .

CARDINAL . At the time of the events the first CARDINAL applicants were employed by a newspaper specialising in investigative journalism . The newspaper was involved in numerous scandals and lawsuits . In DATE its editor in chief was arrested on charges of corruption . According to the applicants , after that event CARDINAL of them developed close relationships with the QUANTITY police officers involved in the arrest of the editor in chief and CARDINAL of them was even involved in a romantic relationship with CARDINAL of the QUANTITY police officers . According to the applicants , the police officers in question provided them with material for their work at the newspaper . The Government disputed the factual circumstances concerning the close relationship between the applicants and the QUANTITY police officers .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE a person calling himself PERSON came to the headquarters of the newspaper employing the first CARDINAL applicants and offered to sell a video containing explicit images of a priest engaged in promiscuous behaviour . It appeared later that PERSON was member of a criminal gang and that the video in question had been used to blackmail the priest . The information was passed on to the QUANTITY police officers and on DATE CARDINAL of the applicants helped the police officers to apprehend Petrus . CARDINAL applicant was remunerated for her assistance and , on DATE , wrote a receipt to ORG . The Government disputed the applicants’ submissions concerning the arrest of PERSON and the applicants’ involvement therein . They confirmed the fact that one of the applicants had received money from ORG , however , without specifying the consideration for the payment .

CARDINAL . Also in DATE one of the first CARDINAL applicants became acquainted with a person named GPE , who was involved in a dispute with ORG about which the applicant wrote an article . On DATE all the applicants , the QUANTITY police officers and GPE spent TIME in a sauna near GPE . The Government disputed the allegation that the QUANTITY police officers had spent time in a sauna with the applicants and with GPE

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant was allegedly contacted by CARDINAL of the QUANTITY police officers and was asked not to publish an article about illegalities at ORG due to appear DATE . The police officer took the applicant to a store , apparently specialising in electronics , where he showed her a video of her and the other applicants filmed on DATE in the sauna and threatened to have it broadcast on national television if his conditions were not met and added that copies of the video would be sent to the applicants’ parents . He also allegedly threatened her with imprisonment and violence and warned her that her collaboration with the police would be made public . The first applicant informed the police officer in question that it was too late to stop the article ’s publication since the material had already been sent to the printing house . On DATE the article in question was published .

CARDINAL . On DATE at TIME the national television service broadcast a programme dedicated to the phenomenon of corruption and the moral character of journalists from the newspaper employing the applicants . The programme was presented by the president of the national television service and GPE was a guest . The guest was presented as a businessman who alleged that he had bribed the second applicant to secure the publication of material . He also described his and the applicants’ TIME in the sauna on DATE , and stated that CARDINAL of the applicants had stolen money from the pocket of his trousers and that the applicants intended to kidnap his child for ransom . GPE also alleged that the newspaper employing the applicants belonged to an opposition leader . The programme continued with footage from a black and white video filmed in the sauna . The applicants were seen in their underwear , apparently intoxicated , using obscene language . CARDINAL of the applicants were kissing and touching one of the men , and CARDINAL of them was performing an erotic dance . The face of the male was covered in the video , whereas those of the applicants were not and the video was paused from time to time in order to allow them to be recognised more easily . The video appears to have been shot from a static camera and CARDINAL of the male participants appears to have been aware of the filming , since he gave the “ thumbs up ” sign to the camera when none of the applicants was looking . A copy of the receipt issued to ORG was also shown in the programme and offensive terms with meanings such as “ low class prostitutes ” were employed when images of the applicants were shown . The programme continued with footage from a video of the arrest of the editor in chief of the newspaper employing the applicants . According to the applicants , that video had been part of a criminal case - file and not for public use . This information was not disputed by the Government . On DATE the programme was broadcast again by the national television service .

CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE the first applicant lodged a criminal complaint about the blackmail which she and her colleagues had been subjected to and about the abuse of power committed by the QUANTITY police officers . She submitted , in particular , that the police officers had invited her and her colleagues to a sauna and secretly filmed them , after which they had attempted to blackmail them with the video .

CARDINAL . NORP In examining the complaint the Prosecutor ’s Office questioned CARDINAL of the applicants , all of whom gave similar accounts of the facts of the case and accused the CARDINAL police officers of the secret filming and blackmail . The police officers were questioned too , and all denied having had close relationships with the applicants and going with them to a sauna on DATE . They denied any implication in the secret filming , the allegations of blackmail and those concerning the transmitting of the video to the national television service . GPE submitted that the video had been shot with his camera and that one of the applicants had accidentally switched the camera on and placed it on a shelf . He had discovered the video DATE and decided to take it to the national television service allegedly in order to prevent CARDINAL of the applicants from kidnapping his child . He alleged not to have known the applicants’ male friends who had been with them in the sauna on DATE .

ORG inquired with ORG whether the first applicant had ever received money in exchange for collaborating with the police and , in particular , whether she had helped bring about the arrest of a person called PERSON . In reply ORG did not answer the first question and stated that ORG had the right to have secret collaborators and remunerate them . ORG also informed ORG that there were no records on anyone named PERSON in its database .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the first applicants’ criminal complaint and refused to initiate criminal proceedings on the ground that the complaint was ill - founded . The first applicant appealed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the hierarchically superior ORG quashed the above - mentioned decision on the ground that the investigation had not been thorough . In particular , it noted that the lower ORG had failed to determine how the receipt issued by CARDINAL of the applicants to ORG was transmitted to the national television service . It was also noted that the payment of money to that applicant was to be checked with ORG , the administrator of the public funds .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG again dismissed the first applicant ’s criminal complaint on the ground that the receipt of CARDINAL DATE did not constitute a ORG secret and that its disclosure to the national television service was not an offence . As to the complaint concerning the alleged abuse of power by the QUANTITY police officers , it was also found to be ill - founded because it had not been established that the applicants had ever assisted in bringing about the arrest of PERSON . The first applicant appealed against this decision and submitted , inter alia , that what she was remunerated for by ORG had not been established . She also submitted that the investigators had failed to examine the original video from the sauna and that they had failed to examine the complaint about blackmail .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the Prosecutor ’s decision of CARDINAL DATE on the ground , inter alia , that ORG had failed to examine the first applicant ’s complaint concerning blackmail .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG again dismissed the criminal complaint lodged by the first applicant on the ground that the dissemination of defamatory information was not an offence under NORP law . The first applicant challenged the decision before the hierarchically superior prosecutor . However , the appeal was dismissed on DATE and a subsequent appeal was finally dismissed by ORG on DATE . On DATE ORG dismissed an extraordinary appeal lodged by the first applicant .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , all the applicants lodged an action with a civil court seeking compensation for the breach of LAW and the national television service . They complained about the unlawful secret filming by the police in the sauna , the disclosure of the applicants’ collaboration with the police and the broadcasting of the video from the sauna on national television . The applicants also complained about the defamatory nature of some of the statements made on the programme aired on national television on DATE . For the alleged breaches they sought compensation in amounts varying CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the part of the applicants’ action against the national television service concerning the broadcasting of the video from the sauna and the defamatory statements made during the programme of DATE . The court considered that there was no public interest in broadcasting the video from the sauna . The rest of the applicants’ action was dismissed as ill - founded , the court finding that the applicants had failed to prove that the video had been shot by the QUANTITY police officers . The applicants appealed .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the ORG appeal against the judgment of ORG of DATE and found ORG responsible for the filming in the sauna on DATE , for blackmailing the applicants and for handing to the national television of the video of the sauna scene and of a copy of the receipt issued to ORG to one of the applicants . The finding was based on the statements made by all the applicants during the criminal investigation , on the fact that the programme of CARDINAL DATE contained images from the video of the arrest of the editor in chief of the newspaper employing CARDINAL of the applicants , a video which was not publicly available ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and on the presence in the programme of a copy of a receipt issued by CARDINAL of the applicants . The judges of ORG also recognised the man making a “ thumbs up ” sign in the video ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) as being CARDINAL of the QUANTITY police officers . The court also found the national television service responsible for broadcasting the video from the sauna . The court ordered the defendants to pay the applicants non - pecuniary damage varying CARDINAL NORP lei ( MDL ) ( the equivalent of QUANTITY ( ORG ) ) and MDL MONEY ( the equivalent of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL ) and compensation for costs and expenses in the amount of MDL MONEY ( the equivalent of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL ) . All the parties lodged appeals on points of law .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG gave a final ruling in the case . It found the statements made during the programme of DATE to the effect that the applicant journalists had been bribed to publish an article and that they intended to kidnap a child defamatory . The court also found that the disclosure by ORG of one of the applicants’ collaboration with the police by way of disclosing a receipt written by her had breached her right to respect for her private life . A similar breach with regard to all the applicants was found in respect of the broadcasting of the video of the sauna scene on national television without their consent and in the absence of a public interest justification . The court also found that the secret filming in the sauna constituted an unjustified interference with the applicants’ right to privacy as guaranteed by LAW . However , relying on the outcome of the criminal investigation , the court found that there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the secret filming of the sauna scene had been carried out by employees of ORG . At the same time the court concluded that ORG was responsible for unlawfully transmitting to the national television service secret video material from a criminal case file , namely , a video of the arrest of the editor in chief of the newspaper employing the first and second applicants .

CARDINAL . ORG ordered the national television service to pay each applicant MDL CARDINAL,CARDINAL ( the equivalent of EUR CARDINAL ) for non - pecuniary damage caused by the broadcasting of the video of the sauna scene . It also ordered the guest on the programme of DATE , GPE , to pay the second applicant MDL CARDINAL ( the equivalent of ORG ) for defamation and ORG to pay MDL CARDINAL ( the equivalent of ORG CARDINAL ) to the first applicant for disclosing her collaboration with the police . The court also ordered the defendants to pay the applicants MDL CARDINAL ( the equivalent of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL ) for costs and expenses . In reducing the amounts awarded by ORG , ORG argued that the awards had to be in compliance with LAW , in force at the time of the events ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the DATE LAW , in force until DATE :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Any natural or legal person shall be entitled to apply to the courts to seek the withdrawal of statements which are damaging to his or her honour and dignity if the person who made such statements can not prove that they are true .

( CARDINAL ) Where such information was made public by a media body , the court shall compel the publishing office of the media body to publish , not DATE after the entry into force of the judicial decision , a withdrawal of the statements in the same column , on the same page or in the same programme or series of broadcasts . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) Damage caused to a person as a result of circulation of statements which do not correspond to reality and are damaging to his or her honour or dignity shall be compensated by the responsible natural or legal person .

( CARDINAL ) The amount awarded shall be determined by the court in each case and shall be between [ CARDINAL lei and CARDINAL lei ] if the information has been circulated by a legal person and between [ CARDINAL lei and CARDINAL lei ] if the information has been circulated by a natural person . ”
